Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a program to support for the American Meteorological Society Summer Policy Colloquium. The goal of this program is to build knowledge, experience and leadership capacity in the intersection of science and policy for individual scientists and for the geosciences as a whole. The workshop participants generally consist of 30 early to mid-career researchers and graduate students. The program exposes the participants to variety of issues related to science and science policy, including: 1) reconciling scientific opportunities and national needs in developing research programs; 2) allocating and managing resources for science; 3) incorporating science and knowledge into policy formulation and the national agenda; 4) strengthening their ability to listen to and understand, as well as educate and inspire other scientists, policymakers, users of science and science-based services, and the general public; 5) understanding the special ethical dimensions and demands of scientific research and scientific leadership; and 6) building understanding of the implications of their science for national security. Course instructors are scientists and others with significant policy experience, which is shared with the workshop participants during a 10-day colloquium in Washington, DC.


Facilitating the interaction among researchers and policy analysts and practitioners is a significant benefit to both groups. The focus on early career individuals, especially the graduate students, is also a strength of the project, providing these individuals with the tools they will need to work together to address important societal problems in which scientific research plays a role. The impacts of the AMS Policy Colloquium, which has been serving the research and science policy communities for more than ten years, can be observed in the influential positions that its alumni (now totaling more than 400 individuals) now hold.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Each year, early in June, the American MeteorologicalSociety runs a Summer Policy Colloquium providing 25-40 early-career scientists and engineers a structured, broadly-based dialog with: (1) policy-level scientist-leaders from both the legislative and executive branches; (2) executives from non-governmental organizations; and (3) policy analysts, science journalists, and other actors in the policy arena. Colloquium participants are given pre-assigned reading and work through group exercises and case studies. Through these and other means they develop a new grasp of and
appreciation for the way the national policy discussion shapes science, and the way science and scientists contribute to policy formulation. Colloquium
participants take important first steps toward becoming as disciplined in their approach to the policy process as they are with respect to their own scientific research.

More than 500 participants – most funded by their respective
host institutions – have completed the program to date. Over the years, the National Science Foundation has provided support for Colloquium participation by over 200 graduate students (and 20 HBCU or MSI faculty) selected by means of a national competitive process on the basis of their intellectual achievements and their potential for leadership.

At the same time the AMS Summer Policy Colloquium helps individual
scientists develop leadership skills, it builds leadership capacity across the
larger geosciences community. Participants learn best practices with respect to allocating and managing resources for science and developing options for
policymakers. The Colloquium experience helps them work effectively with
policymakers to infuse scientific understanding into policy formulation and the
national agenda with respect to natural resources, environmental protection,
and resilience to hazards. Participants hone a range of communication skills – especially their ability to listen to and respond to the needs of other scientists, policymakers, users of science and science-based services, and the general public. They become familiar with the special ethical challenges confronting scientist-leaders. They learn from journalists and policymakers how to communicate in ways that encourage information sharing and collaboration rather than confrontation and divisiveness. They build their understanding of the broader implications of their science for national security and geopolitical stability. Colloquium participants learn directly from policy makers at the highest levels of government, in both the executive and legislative branches, and from leaders of private enterprise and NGO’s, rather than secondhand through academics. Most (though not all) of the Colloquium panelists and discussion leaders have themselves been educated as scientists. By sharing their experiences, they help Colloquium participants to spot and avoid pitfalls that often trip up novices in the policy arena.

participants with tools, habits, and motivation they need for lifelong
learning. The Colloquium is also a portal for scientists seeking to contribute
